column1: Supplemental Table 3. Concentrations ([C] and [N]) for plants and animals sampled in Yosemite National Park
column4: 2007. Digest [N] and [C] of plants (n = 134) and animals (n = 29) were calculated using the equations below. Digestible concentrations for Quercus spp. and Pinus spp. were calculated using the USDA National Nutrient Database (Table S4). Some data was also published as on-line material in Hopkins and Ferguson (2011; in Press)

column1: Digest DM = mean data compiled by Robbins et al. (2002)
Digest N (plants) = % N x 0.9 (assuming 90% of % N is digestible)
Digest N (animals) = % N x 1 (assuming 100% of % N is digestible)
Digest N (acorn and pinenut) = % N x 0.466 (assuming acorn digestibility is similar to pinenut digestibility; Mealey 1980)
Digest C (plants) = Digest DM x 0.45 (assuming Digest DM is 45% C for fruit and leafy plants; Koch and Phillips 2002)
Digest C (animals) = 51.50 (determined by Phillips and Koch 2002)
Koch, P. L., and D. L. Phillips. 2002. Incorporating concentration dependence in stable isotope mixing models: a reply to Robbins, Hilderbrand and Farley. Oecologia 133:14–18.

Mealey, S. P. 1980. The natural food habits of grizzly bears in Yellowstone National Park, 1973-1974. Page 281–292 in C. J. Markinka and K. L. McArthur, editors. Bears—their biology and management: proceedings, fourth international conference on bear research and management. Bear Biology Association, Kalispell, Montana, USA.
Phillips D. L., and P. L. Koch. 2002. Incorporating concentration dependence in stable isotope mixing models. Oecologia 130:114–125.
Robbins C. T., G. V. Hilderbrand, and S. D. Farley. 2002. Incorporating concentration dependence in stable isotope mixing models: a response to Phillips and Koch (2002). Oecologia 133:10–13.
